comments.commentBody: They've taken great pains, over decades, to devise and implement all the parts of the plan that has brought us to this moment. This is all their doing. All this deregulation of everything, all of the groups like ALEC, Heritage, Grover Norquist, the NRA, Family Research Council, and many others. They're coordinated. They're relentless.

It would be very appropriate to see it swept off so easily. I think they seeded their crop of weeds rather well for almost four decades while we were busy enjoying the flowers. It will take more than half the people voting to undo and it takes grass roots efforts to weed them out of the State legislature and governorships as well. Scott Walker remains in his office as too Perry and the others. Exploiting worked and been at it since the supposed Welfare Queens. The weeds have a good root system. Have a lot of strong organizations and money without end from those who would rape and pillage as they want, ever more. They worked tirelessly to get to here and it has divided us and made some of the worst very wealthy. Some even pay so little the employees must depend on welfare to cover the gaps and the lords of the cabals want to end this too.

We live in a time of flux.  Increasing wealth and income inequality cause fissures in our society as do changing demographics.  The GOP has chosen to exploit these divisions rather than heal them as the long term interests of the nation demand.  If it persists with its delusional tactics, it will relegate itself to the dust heap of history.

Governor Kasich is surprising me but in a positive way. The Medicaid expansion means that people in his state will have health care and that is wonderful.  Hopefully he will surprise people in more good ways but that is doubtful.
President Sanders and V.P. Grayson. If only.

While I respect and admire your well-thought-out and written opinions (including most of this one), I can't agree at all that this story is "bigger and more important than Watergate."  Watergate involved Presidential misconduct and likely impeachment (had President Nixon not preemptively resigned).  This story, to me at least, is more comparable to the 1975 Church Committee hearings and report on CIA (and NSA and FBI) abuses following the Watergate scandal.  The question is whether we'll get the kind of leadership from Senator Feinstein that even remotely approaches the courageous leadership of Senator Church and his colleagues nearly four decades ago.

I like your comment about President Sanders but we all know this will never happen. Most people do not want to be told the truth about anything. This is why we always end up with demigods being elected to our highest political offices.

Greenwald is right about being arrested, were he to return home. If anything, the administration has shown, over and over, that it will act with impunity whenever it perceives a threat. Greenwald is a huge threat to a system run amok. Aside from a handful of legislators, an overwhelming majority in Congress support the Patriot Act and the NSA's mission (whatever it is). None are perturbed in the least by the notion that is out in the open: every single American is under watch, suspected of something they might have done in the past, may be doing at this moment, or will in the future. The NSA investigates pre-crime, the idea represented in the movie "Minority Report."

Greenwald's assured his place in history for having broken a story that is even bigger and more important than Watergate. What he does with this story in the months and years to come, may assure his place in history as the Libertarian thinker who shocked America awake. Maybe.

I've commented elsewhere that what America lacks is straight news. Sure, we have AP. Now, all we have is propaganda. Want news? Surf the internets... These days, it is impossible to find one source of comprehensive news. Local news (here in Los Angeles) are abysmal. I'm not fond of our local paper, either. That is why I mostly read the Times...

As for Glenn being able to come back and be assured he will be free, I wouldn't come back until the Patriot Act is repealed and the law is signed by President Sanders. Be safe, Glenn! Thank you!

Stop and frisk may be legally suspect, but it is undoubtedly saving the lives of urban youth. It is ironic that only a few miles away in Newark NJ, we can see what NYC would be like without it. Every single day there is a senseless death of a black or Latino youth often with innocent by standees as "collateral damage".

I sympathize with those who resent the indignity of the searches, but the trade off would seem worth it. The communities effected need to careful what they wish for....

What evidence can you cite showing that stop and frisk has had some effect on lessening gun violence and 'saving lives?' There is a welter of evidence that it has made some people fear the police, and not because they've committed a crime. When can we expect them to start stopping people suspected of cocaine possession coming and going from Park Avenue condos?

I find it difficult to understand how so many people don't get the simple concept behind civil rights, and why a retroactive view of "crime reduction" is a particularly egregious and dangerous violation of those rights.

i can't see how so many people seem to get basic facts wrong about this case: read it again, the policy allowed officers to stop if they DID NOT suspect. they simply stopped all men of color. sounds ridiculous, right? i witnessed it many times.

Logic has prevailed. I find it difficult to understand how so many people can not grasp the necessity of allowing officers to stop if they suspect. The violent crime rates are sadly higher in minority areas of the city, so of course a large percentage of individuals stopped are minorities. The city is unable to impose tougher gun laws, few options are left in order to try to get people who own guns to at least think twice before leaving the house with one, whereas if they know they can not legally be stopped then of course the hesitation stops. Instead of people worrying about their civil liberties with this issue they should be concerned and show as much determination to lessen gun violence to save lives.

There is a significant difference.  In 'stop and frisk' cases an officer must have some reasonable suspicion to make the stop and search of an individual.  In a road block everyone is caught up in the same net and suspicion, or probable cause, is not a factor at all.  Of course, to make a 'stop' doesn't require much cause.  In Memphis we call it 'Driving While Black."

The obvious difference is that road blocks stop everyone.  Officers have no discretion.  On the other hand, Terry stop and frisks are left entirely to the police officer's discretion.  Every assiduous examination of New York's stop and frisk "procedure" has shown that it disproportionately affects minorities.  Indeed, that is what Judge Sheindlin -- a well respected and extremely circumspect jurist -- found.

The difference is a police road block stops EVERY car, ostensibly to discover drunk drivers, with the added bonus of discovering a driver with an expired license, no registration, insurance, etc.  "Stop and frisk" does not stop every person passing a road block because there is no road block.  The people who the police stop are stopped most often for nothing more than "looking suspicious", matching a profile and other non-specific reasons.

The difference is actually quite clear. At a roadblock they stop every single car. In other words, everyone is treated equally.

This is not the case with Stop and Frisk. Or are you suggest that the police stop and frisk every single pedestrian at a given intersection?

The difference would be if they only stopped cars with white people in them and not cars with African Americans or Latinos.  They are not stopping everybody. They are selectively stopping people based on their race.
Our country seeks to make criminals for its best industry, the criminal justice system, next to the best of best industries - the war machine.
"unethical, unprofessional" - exactly my impression of this judge. She should be removed from the bench.

It seems to me that the problem with Stop and Frisk is not the law itself but the way in which it is implemented. The problem is the egregious abuse and disrespect that many of the young men who are stopped are forced to endure. I have seen and read many statements by residents (including young men) of some of the high-crime communities in which S&F is most often—but not exclusively—practiced; many have stated that they are grateful for the visible police presence and the concomitant reduction in violent crime. They support the law! However, when the police behave like rude and abusive bullies—as they all too often do—that is when problems arise. I think having every single police encounter with the public recorded on video and re-training and mandating that beat cops treat the public with the utmost respect would go a long way toward correcting the problems with the existing law.

Keep in mind that the appellate  court said "nothing" about the merits of this case.  It may well be true that the NYPD is in fact terrorizing innocent citizens in that Brooklyn neighborhood.  Indeed, your own comments suggest that the "Up against the wall" tactics were not necessary when you were with the NYPD.  The questions remain:  were the statistical presentations that were so much a part of this case valid?   jflynn

"we never just did the "up against the wall" routine on a shotgun basis"
"What we have here is another limo liberal attempting to place her opinion & politics ahead of the greater good of all New Yorkers."

Umm, I think you contradicted yourself there: You were engaged in effective policing because you only went after people who the residents were telling you were dangerous and armed (i.e. had probable cause). Stop & frisk, by contrast, is *ineffective* policing, because it goes after all people who are non-white men for being non-white men, and alienates those very residents you got tips from.

Oh, and her opinion isn't just her opinion, it's the the Fourth Amendment, which was written specifically to prevent the government from just randomly searching people.

When I was with the NYPD in the 60s & 70s, it was the residents who tipped us off to people carrying weapons and we never just did the "up against the wall" routine on a shotgun basis. It is perhaps ironic that the neighborhood in Brooklyn that Justice Scheindlin resides in is now much safer due to more effective policing.

What we have here is another limo liberal attempting to place her opinion & politics ahead of the greater good of all New Yorkers. This "smack down" was appropriate and in the best interest of the City. Justice Scheindlin should retire forthwith.

The essential difference is that road blocks stop every car that comes through, subjects each driver to the same treatment, and then using information gained at the stop increases the level of intrusion if the facts support it. The testimony at this trial concluded that for over 87% of the stop and frisks, there was no reason for the stop at all and no violation of law was found. The fact that the people who were stopped were more than 90% Black and Latino led the court to conclude that race was the predominant factor in determining who was stopped. The search was independent of anything the officer observed or found prior to the search. Would you have the same "respect for the law" if when you approached the road block, you were stopped because you were _____ race or _______ nationality (insert your race or nationality), removed from your car and forced to perform roadside sobriety tests and blow into an alco-sensor before the cop asked you a single question, and every one else was let through? A "Whites Only" or "Irish Only" road block would certainly not conform to your "good of the town" argument.

The difference is the road blocks stopped every car ( or every nth car) and therefore did not engage in profiling or targeted stops.
.
The cases would be similar if those police road blocks were far disproportionately stopping black and Hispanic drivers. Presumably they didn't.

It doesn't matter if it works or not, what matters if it's legal. Torture may work sometimes, but that doesn't make it legal. Was I the only person who actually followed the trial and read the judge's carefully-worded ruling?
Folks, profiling is not based on race. It is based on background, actions, behavior, etc... The color of your skin makes zero difference.

"...Being that the program is actually "Stop, question, and frisk if warranted" .. stop should only be made for a reason, not based on the color of your skim; frisk - only if warranted. But thousands of cases showed that it is not how it is conducted. The rules of the program must be changed.

Tall people are much more likely to commit crimes than short people. Should we arrest tall people as a preventive measure? dark-haired people are much more likely that those with blond hair. Should we..? You can put forward any propositions, but we have a constitution (equal protection clause) and laws - you cannot treat person based on which group (s)he belongs.
The difference is that all drivers are stopped and scrutinized for alcohol, not just drivers in black cars.

Dear John,
While I fully agree with you, in a way your question is rather rhetorical: indeed, these would be the New York Time reporters who should've mentioned the Clinton's appointees. And you're so naïve to expect such an objectivity from this paper?
Still, with all its biases and shortcomings, the NYT is, IMHO, the best (more accurately the less bad, lol) broadly circulated newspaper in this country. Perhaps, since I had been born and brought up in a communist country, my ability to read between the lines helps me to tease out the wheat from the chaff.
The headline would have been "GOP Judges Approve Racist Police Tactic".

I think more important is the power of the police and the mayor in appealing this case. As a liberal outsider, I have always endorsed Mayor Bloomberg and the appellate judges could have similar proclivities, regardless of who appointed them. But you can't imply that they would let their political leanings determine the outcome of this case, except insofar as they line up according to a cross-party line, which is evident in where I stand.

If the three - or even if two of the three - appellate judges who removed Judge Scheindlin from the case had been appointed by Republican presidents, wouldn't that fact have worked its way into the New York Times story?  Shouldn't the fact that two of the three appellate judges who unanimously removed her were appointed by President Clinton have been mentioned by the reporter?

And making war on the poor and middle class should not make sense to capitalists, really.  Capitalism relies on consumers, and it's a fact that the poor spend the highest percentage of their resources, while the rich spend the least on consumer goods.  The middle class is in the middle, but the health of the economy depends on them to consume.  They are the true job creators, and it's mystifying why conservatives don't see this.

It may be that Google and Yahoo! feel willing and able to secure their networks.  But it's also possible that they are playing the PR game with users, while turning a blind eye toward government surveillance in order to secure cooperation (regulatory, tax, etc.).  Given their business models, and our current political climate, I'd bet on the latter.

Ed, the word isn't "ironic", it's "hypocritical." Or, more likely, Facebook and Google just don't want the competition from the Feds. They want the data collection business all to themselves, apparently, Clearly they view the N.S.A. as too effective a competitor. Maybe they will all join the "starve the government" movement, hoping to defund the N.S.A. All in the name of privacy of course.

The truly sad part of all this is that millions of Americans who (justly) scream bloody murder about government invasion of their privacy, have no hesitation in turning over endless personal information to private corporations. When it comes to accountability, the government with all its many, many flaws is still much more accountable to America and its citizens than are any of these tech giants.

True, and I'm no fan of social media, but the most significant difference is that while Facebook, Google, etc. collect obscene amounts of personal information from their users, they can't arrest you. Yet.
Sure, but at least their consumers are aware and agree (to the terms technically) at least.

Ironic these companies are so obsessed with user security since they profit mightily from extracting every bit of personal data they can from those same users.  It would appear that their outrage is a tad hypocritical given they subsist on taking pretty much whatever personal information they want from their users...if they could convert the government "spying" into revenue, they'd probably support that too
